name: melopsittacus-undulatus
definition: The budgerigar is a long-tailed, seed-eating parrot usually nicknamed the budgie, or in American English, the parakeet.
description:
Found wild throughout the drier parts of Australia, prior to colonisation, budgerigar had survived harsh inland conditions for five million years.

It displays a light green body colour, while their mantles display pitch-black mantle markings edged in clear yellow undulations.

The forehead and face is yellow in adults.

Their wings have greenish-black flight feathers and black coverts with yellow fringes along with central yellow flashes.

The tail is dark-blue and outside tail feathers display central yellow flashes.

Prior to their adult plumage, young individuals have blackish stripes down to the nose in young individuals until around 3 to 4 months of age.

Wild budgerigar average length is 18 centimeters, wingspan is 30 centimeters and weigh 30 to 40 grams.

Juveniles and chicks are monomorphic, while adults are told apart by their cere colouring, and their behaviour.

Wild budgies eat a variety of grass seeds, fruits, berries, and vegetation. They feed on or near the ground. What they eat varies with food availability during different seasons.

Budgerigars are opportunistic breeders and respond to rains when grass seeds become most abundant.

Nests are made in holes in trees, fence posts or logs lying on the ground; the four to six eggs are incubated for 18 to 21 days, with the young fledging about 30 days after hatching.

They show signs of affection to their flockmates by preening or feeding one another.

Budgerigars feed one another by eating the seeds themselves, and then regurgitating it into their flockmate's mouth.

First recorded in 1805, budgerigars are popular pets around the world due to their small size, low cost, and ability to mimic human speech.

Breeders have worked to produce a variety of colour, pattern and feather mutations, including albino, blue, cinnamon-ino, clearwinged, crested, dark, greywinged, opaline, pieds, spangled, dilute and violet.

They are the third most popular pet in the world, after the domesticated dog and cat.

Budgerigars are social animals and require stimulation in the shape of toys and interaction with humans or with other budgerigars.

The budgerigar is closely related to lories and the fig parrots.

The main predators of the wild budgerigar are snakes and birds of prey such as hawks.

featured.caption:
Researchers has found that budgerigar flies at just two speed levels.

They noted that slow mode is approximately half the speed of fast mode. Also that the faster mode of flight was the most efficient for the birds.

related.definition: The blue-and-yellow macaw is a large South American parrot with mostly blue top parts and light orange underparts, with gradient hues of green on top of its head.
The red-tailed black cockatoo is a large black cockatoo native to Australia. It is more common in the drier parts of the continent.
